In a time when every medical procedure has become more expensive and harder to access, LASIK has become cheaper, safer, and far more common.

Why? Because LASIK isn't covered by insurance or any government program. You have to pay for it out of your own pocket. Therefore they must compete for your dollars. Also, because you're paying for it, you shop around. You compare prices -- and those prices are CLEARLY stated up-front! You get reviews from other patients. The doctors who perform these surgeries know all of this, and they therefore do their best to give you the best possible experience for the least possible cost.

The entire concept of a 3rd-party-payer for medical procedures is something we need to end. Like LASIK, if we made doctors and hospitals compete for your business, prices would go down, and quality would go up. That's what ALWAYS happens when businesses compete. But for some reason, the vast majority of people are convinced that such competition won't work in the healthcare industry. (And YES, I KNOW you can't shop around when you're having a life-threatening emergency -- but when the cost of all the non emergency procedures go down, so will the costs of the emergency procedures. They'll be dragged down by the overall cost-cutting in the healthcare industry.)

And, no, I don't mean ban health insurance -- a catastrophic illness definitely requires some sort of insurance. But, like your homeowner's insurance doesn't cover the replacement of a worn-out roof or a broken A/C compressor, and your car insurance doesn't cover things like new tires or oil changes, neither should your health insurance cover anything other than hugely catastrophic incidents. Everything else should be paid for out of your pocket, and the prices for all of those services should be clearly listed up front and/or negotiated by you and your doctor.

LASIK is proof positive that such a system will work. Very, very well. Competition always makes things better for the consumer. Every. Single. Time.

I design manual surgical instruments for cataract surgery, and a quick bit of clarification on the cataract surgery side: the "tiny needle with a vibrating tip" is called phacoemulsification, which involves a needle moving in and out 35,000-45,000 times per second which emulsifies the lens (essentially liquefying it) before sucking it out of the eye with the same needle. It should also be noted that the vast majority of cataracts are extracted using phacoemulsification not femptosecond lasers, although there are more and more surgeons using this technique every year. It has great surgical advantages, but the cost it passes to the patient limits its widespread use, and only some patients choose the laser-assisted surgery as an add-on to the classic phaco-technique.

In the 1950s, the microkeratome and keratomileusis technique were developed in Bogotá, Colombia, by the Spanish ophthalmologist Jose Barraquer. In his clinic, he would cut thin (one hundredth of a mm thick) flaps in the cornea to alter its shape. Barraquer also investigated how much of the cornea had to be left unaltered in order to provide stable long-term results. This work was followed by that of the Russian scientist, Svyatoslav Fyodorov. With out Barraquer, Fyodorov couldn't do anything. Please do not erase us from history as a trivial foot note.

I wore glasses all my life since I was 8. I was nearsighted with astigmatism. Two years ago, I elected to have PRK (PhotoRefractive Keratectomy., which is actually the precursor to the LASIK procedure, but both have been modernized and improved greatly with technology and techniques. It involves scraping off the topmost layer of the cornea and using careful measurements to reshape the the inner cornea using the laser. PRK is good for people who rub their eyes a lot, pilots, astronauts, athletes and others who stand a higher risk of damaging their post-LASIK eyes. LASIK involves cutting a flap in the cornea and the resealing it. That reseal "wound" is still there and pressure, touching and impacts can dislocate the healing flap. The drawback is that PRK takes quite a bit longer to heal than LASIK--up to a couple of weeks. My surgery went fantastic. I have even better vision now than I ever did wearing glasses.

I was a bit scared of getting the procedure done, since I wasn't too comfortable with being able to see what was going on and being unable to close my eyes. So before I went in, I watched a POV video of the surgery being performed over and over to get used to it. What I didn't realize was that you're only able to clearly see what's going on for around the first and last 5% of the process, other than that, everything is blurry! I laid down in the chair, they put some medicine in my eye, then a machine put pressure on it, everything slowly went blurry, a bunch of stuff happened, the surgeon said to focus on the red light, then my vision came back when he put the flap back in place. I got all worked-up over nothing!
